questions.question: The most common valvular heart disease in pregnancy is
What is the commonest congenital valvular lesion observed in pregnancy?
questions.explanation: 510Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is the commonest congenital valvular lesion observed inpregnancy. Mitral stenosis is the commonest acquired heart lesion during pregnancy.Condition in pregnancyCongenital heart diseaseCongenital valvular lesionCyanotic Congenital Heart diseaseAcquired valvular heart diseaseMost common lesionAtrial septal defectMitral valve prolapseTetrology of FallotMitral stenosis > Mitral regurgitation > Aortic stenosis

questions.question: A 24-year-old lady with rheumatic mitral stenosis becomes pregnant. At what point duringheryou be least concerned about her developing cardiac failure?pregnancy would
questions.explanation: Cardiac failure in pregnancy is least likely to occur during 24 weeks, considering the givenoptions.The order of risk of cardiac failure in pregnancy is immediate postpartum > 2nd stage of labor> 30 weeks > 22 weeks.Maternal cardiac risk predictors: [Mnemonic: NOPE]N-NYHA class >2O-Obstructive lesions of left heart (Mitral valve area <2 cm2 or aortic valve area <1.5 cm2,peak LV outflow tract gradient >30 mmHg)P-Prior cardiac events before pregnancyE-Ejection fraction <40%Scoring systems used to calculate risk are Cardiac Disease in Pregnancy (CARPREG) andZAHARA Scores.

questions.question: An intern posted in the antenatal OPD auscultates a patient who came for her routinecheckup. Presence of which of the following features would not suggest a physiological changeof pregnancy?

options.B: Ejection systolic murmur at left sternal border
options.C: Continuous murmur at 2nd to 4th intercostal space

questions.explanation: Late systolic murmur is pathological in pregnancy.CVS physiological changes in pregnancy:• Pulse rate: Increases• Diastolic BP: Decreases•S1: Loud and split• S2:Normal• S3:prominent (occasional)•Jugular venous distension and venous hum511• Murmurs•••Ejection systolic murmur at left sternal border.Continous murmur at 2nd-4th intercostal space (known as mammary souffle)Heart is displaced upwards and to the left• ECG changes• Left axis deviation (due to elevation of diaphragm)•T wave inversion, biatrial enlargement• Mild ST changes in the inferior leads•Premature atrial and ventricular contractions are relatively frequent.

questions.question: Which of the following is not an absolute indication for therapeutic termination ofpregnancy?
questions.explanation: Prosthetic valve replacement is not an indication for therapeutic termination as it comes underthe WHO category risk 3. Only conditions included under WHO category risk 4 are considered asindications for termination of pregnancy.WHO class 4 comprises of diseases with very high risk of maternal mortality or severe morbidity,such as:• Pulmonary arterial hypertension• Severe systemic ventricular dysfunction (NYHA III-IV or LVEF 30-40%)• Previous peripartum cardiomyopathy with any residual impairment of left ventricular function•Severe left heart obstruction• Marfan syndrome with aorta dilated >40 mmTermination of pregnancy is also advised in patients with Eisenmenger syndrome.

questions.question: A pregnant lady with heart failure planned for valve replacement surgery is posted forcesarean section. Which of the following is not a cardiac indication for cesarean delivery?
questions.explanation: Primary pulmonary hypertension is not a cardiac indication for caesarean delivery.In primary pulmonary hypertension, maternal mortality is about 50% and the majority die (75%)postpartum.Simpson's criteria for cesarean delivery for cardiac disease in pregnancy:• Dilated aortic root >4 cm or aortic aneurysm•• Acute severe congestive heart failure• Recent myocardial infarction• Severe symptomatic aortic stenosis•• Warfarin administration within 2 weeks of delivery512• Need for emergency valve replacement immediately after deliveryCoarctation of the aorta and aortic dissection are other indications for cesarean delivery.In general, vaginal delivery is preferred, and labor induction is usually safe. Cesarean delivery islimited to obstetric indications, and considerations are given for the specific cardiac lesions only.Epidural anesthesia is given during LSCS in heart disease. The major problem withepidural/spinal analgesia is maternal hypotension. This is especially dangerous in women withintracardiac shunts in whom flow may be reversed (blood passes from right to left and bypassesthe lungs). So in case of a shunt lesion, only general anesthesia should be given.

questions.question: You are performing CPR on a woman who is 38-weeks pregnant. She was admitted to theemergency after a massive pulmonary embolism led to cardio-pulmonary arrest. Despite theinitial management of airway, oxygenation and vasopressor support, there is noimprovement. What is the cut off time for perimortem cesarean delivery in this patient?
questions.explanation: Perimortem cesarean delivery should be considered if there is no return of spontaneouscirculation in 5 minutes, according to the AHA 2020 Guidelines.The goal of perimortem cesarean section (PMCS) should be primarily aimed at saving the life ofthe mother. PMCS improves maternal survival by decreasing compression of the IVC by the graviduterus. This improves venous return and diaphragmatic displacement, which in turn improvesrespiratory dynamics.Cardiac Arrest in PregnancyIn Hospital ACLS AlgorithmContinue BLS/ ACLSHigh-quality CPRDefibrillation when indicatedOther ACLS interventions (eg. epinephrine)Assemble the maternal cardiac arrest teamConsider etiology of arrestPerform maternal interventions- Perform airway managementAdminister 100% O2, avoidexcess ventilationPlace IV above the diaphragmIf receiving IV Magnesium, stopand give calcium chloride orgluconatePerformobstetric interventionsProvide continuous lateral uterinedisplacementDetach fetal monitorsPrepare for perimortem cesareandeliveryContinue BCLS/ ACLSHigh-quality CPRDefibrillation when indicatedOther ACLS interventions(eg, epinephrine)Perform PerimortemCesarean deliveryIf no ROSC in 5 minutes,consider immediate perimortemcesarean deliveryNeonatal team to receive neonateOMARROW

questions.question: 505A G2P1 patient with mitral valve prolapse goes into labor. Which of the following should notbe done in the management of this patient?

options.A: Cut short second stage of labour using ventouse
options.D: Trendelenburg position during first stage of labor

questions.explanation: Lateral recumbent position is advised during the first stage of labor in this patient.Management of labor in patients with heart disease:First stage:•Lateral recumbent or propped up position•Oxygen administration (5 to 6 L/min)513•Analgesia by epidural• Fluids should not be infused more than 75 ml/h•Prophylactic antibiotics for bacterial endocarditis during labour and 48 h after delivery• Central venous pressure monitoringSecond stage:• No maternal pushing• Cut short second stage by forceps or ventouse under pudendal and/or perineal block anaesthsia⚫ The benefit of avoiding haemodynamic fluctuations resulting from pushing must be weighedagainst an increased risk of perineal trauma, haemorrhage and fetal head injury with forceps orvacuum delivery.Third stage:⚫ Oxytocin by infusion•• IV frusemide if needed

questions.question: A pregnant woman with cardiac disease is on warfarin therapy. When will the final switch toheparin be advised?
questions.explanation: The final switch to heparin in a pregnant women is advised at 36 weeks of pregnancy and iscontinued till 7 days postpartum.This switch is made from warfarin to heparin at 36 weeks, as warfarin is a strong anticoagulantwhich can cause post partum hemorrhage in the mother at the time of labour and can also crossthe placenta into the fetal blood and can increase the risk of intracranial hemorrhage in the fetusThe below given algorithm is followed for administration of anticoagulants in a pregnant female:LMWH-low molecular weight heparinUFH- Unfractionated heparinPeriod of pregnancyFirst trimesterFrom12 weeks to 36 weeksAt 36 weeks1 week before EDD / 3 days before EDDOn the day of deliveryAnticoagulation of choiceIf dose of warfarin< 5mg/day-continue warfarin till 36 weeksIf dose ofwarfarin > 5mg/day or warfarin embryopathypresent-replace it with heparin / LMWHwarfarinSwitch toLMWHSwitch to UFH(as LMWH have longer T1/2- increased chances of PPH)Stop all anticoagulant514Period of pregnancy6 hrs after vaginal delivery /6-12 hrs after cesareanAnticoagulation of choiceRestart UFH and Warfarin.When INR is 2.5 to 3 withdraw UFH & continue warfarin

questions.question: A 28-year-old G2P1 was admitted to the labor room at 38 weeks of gestation. She is a knowncase of mitral valve prolapse. Which of the following is the best for managing the second stageof labor in this patient?
questions.explanation: The best technique for managing the second stage of labor in a patient with heart disease is usingventouse.For most cardiac patients, vaginal delivery is preferred and cesarean section is reserved forobstetric indications since the cesarean section is associated with more blood loss and higherthromboembolic and infection risk. If vaginal delivery is selected as the mode of choice, it will beconducted with the laboring woman in an upright position, or in the left decubitus position. Thisminimizes aortocaval compression.Active pushing during the second stage may also be limited, depending on the degree of cardiaccompromise. In moderate to severe cardiac disease, it may be prudent to completely avoid anactive second stage. Regional anesthesia can be used to allow the fetal head to descend to theperineum without active pushing. Delivery can be further facilitated by forceps or vacuumextraction.The benefit of avoiding hemodynamic fluctuations resulting from pushing must be weighedagainst an increased risk of perineal trauma, hemorrhage, and fetal head injury with forceps orvacuum delivery.Some journals report that ventouse is preferable to forceps, as it can be applied without puttingthe patient in lithotomy position (raising the legs increases the cardiac load) however it iscontroversial.

questions.question: General anesthesia is the preferable mode of analgesia in pregnant women with
questions.explanation: In pregnant ladies with intracardiac shunts, general anesthesia is the preferable mode ofanalgesia.The major problem with epidural/spinal analgesia is maternal hypotension. This is especiallydangerous in women with intracardiac shunts in whom flow may be reversed (blood passes fromright to left and bypasses the lungs). So in case of a shunt lesion, only general anesthesia shouldbe given.Note: Aortic stenosis will also be affected by the hypotension caused by epidural/spinal analgesia.However, in aortic stenosis, slow epidural anesthesia is adequate and doesn't compromiseventricular preload. Only a few severe cases of aortic stenosis warrant GA. Hence, in the context ofthis MCQ, 'intracardiac shunts' would be the most appropriate answer.515

questions.question: A pregnant lady with mitral stenosis requires anticoagulation. Which of the followingstatements is false regarding her management?

options.A: LMWH or UFH is used until 13 weeks of pregnancy
options.B: From 13 weeks till close to delivery substitute UFH with warfarin
options.C: Following vaginal delivery, anticoagulation with LMWH or UFH is restarted after 6 hours

questions.explanation: Warfarin is not contraindicated during lactation.Warfarin, low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), unfractionated heparin (UFH) do notaccumulate in breast milk. They do not induce an anticoagulant effect in the infant.The choice of anticoagulants is the main problem in pregnancy due to the following reasons:• Warfarin: Although safe for the mother, can lead to warfarin embryopathy, miscarriage, IUGR,and stillbirths.•Heparin: It is safe for the fetus as it does not cross the placenta but less effective than warfarin.⚫ LMWH: Inadequate and ACOG does not recommend its use in pregnant women with prostheticheart valves.If the patient delivers when the anticoagulant is still effective and bleeds excessively, thenprotamine sulfate is given intravenously.Period of gestationTill 12 completed weeks13 to 36 weeks36 weeks to 6 hours before delivery6 hours after vaginal and 24hours after cesarian sectionAnticoagulantLMWH or UFHWarfarinLMWH or UFHLMWH or UFH (ACOG recommendation)

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding hypertrophic cardiomyopathy inpregnancy?

options.A: Most affected patients are asymptomatic during pregnancy
options.B: Diuretics are generally not used in this patient
options.C: She may develop chest pain, palpitations, and syncope
options.D: The most common cause for death is cardiac failure

questions.explanation: The most common cause of death in HOCM in pregnant women is ventricular tachyarrhythmias.Most affected women are asymptomatic, but some patients may develop:•• Dyspnea•Anginal or atypical chest pain•Syncope• Arrhythmias.Strenuous exercise is prohibited during pregnancy. Abrupt positional changes are avoided toprevent reflex vasodilation and decrease of preload. Diuretics and vasodilators are generally notused as they decrease preload. If angina develops, beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers areused.The mode of delivery depends upon obstetric indications and if cesarean section is done, generalanesthesia is considered the safest.516

questions.question: All are true regarding peripartum cardiomyopathy except

options.A: Development of cardiac failure within 5 months of delivery

questions.explanation: Left ventricular systolic dysfunction is a feature of peripartum cardiomyopathy (also known aspostpartum cardiomyopathy) and not diastolic dysfunction.Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy. It develops duringthe last month of pregnancy or within the first 5 months following delivery.The predisposing factors include Cardiac gene mutations involving several genes like TTNC1,TTN, and STAT3, Twin pregnancy/ multifetal gestation, Smoking, and Preeclampsia. Otherproposed causes include viral myocarditis, abnormal immune response to pregnancy,malnutrition, inflammation, etc.PPCM is associated with increased secretion of prolactin by the pituitary and antiangiogenicmolecule sFlt-1 (soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase) by the placenta at term gestation.Pearson's diagnostic criteria for PPCM:• Development of cardiac failure in the last month of pregnancy or within 5 months after delivery• Absence of an identifiable cause for the cardiac failure• Absence of recognizable heart disease prior to the last month of pregnancy, and• Left ventricular systolic dysfunction demonstrated by echocardiographic criteria, such asejection fraction <45% or fractional shortening <30% along with a dilated left ventricle.Management involves treating the features of heart failure. Bromocriptine has been found usefulin this condition. Many women recover within 6 months of delivery, while some continue to haveresidual effects.

questions.question: Which of the following agents has been proposed to be responsible for peripartumcardiomyopathy?
questions.explanation: Prolactin has been proposed to be responsible for peripartum cardiomyopathy.Oxidative stress during late pregnancy leads to the proteolytic cleavage of prolactin. The resulting16-kDa prolactin fragment has been found to be cardiotoxic and can impair the metabolism andcontractility of cardiomyocytes.The etiology of peripartum cardiomyopathy remains unknown. Many potential causes have beenproposed but are not proven.• Viral myocarditis• Abnormal immune response to pregnancy• Abnormal response to the increased hemodynamic burden of pregnancy• Malnutrition• Inflammation•Apoptosis• Prolactin517

questions.question: A P1L1 lady presents with complaints of fatigue and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea 3 monthsafter her delivery. On examination, she has pedal edema and echo shows left ventricularsystolic dysfunction. Which of the following drugs has shown to be effective for the treatmentof her condition?
questions.explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of peripartum cardiomyopathy and bromocriptine is effective forits treatment.Oxidative stress during late pregnancy leads to the proteolytic cleavage of prolactin. The resulting16-kDa prolactin fragment has been found to be cardiotoxic and can impair the metabolism andcontractility of cardiomyocytes. Based on this proposed mechanism, bromocriptine therapy hasbeen suggested because it inhibits prolactin secretion.

questions.question: A 34-year-old lady came to the antenatal OPD with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. Her UPT ispositive. She is a known case of mitral stenosis for 5 years. Which is the best time to dosurgery for mitral stenosis in this patient?
questions.explanation: The best time of surgery for mitral stenosis in pregnancy is between 14-18 weeks.Balloon valvuloplasty is the procedure of choice for mitral stenosis in pregnancy. Any cardiacsurgery in pregnancy should usually be postponed until after delivery, but if required, it can beperformed safely in the 2nd trimester.

questions.question: A lady with ventricular septal defect becomes pregnant. Which of the following is not acommon complication that is expected to occur in this patient?
questions.explanation: Hypertension is a common maternal complication of congenital cardiac disease in pregnancy.The common maternal complications in patients with congenital cardiac disease include:•Congestive cardiac failure• Pulmonary edema• Arrhythmia.Hypertension

questions.question: What is the most common arrhythmia encountered in pregnancy?508
questions.explanation: The most common arrhythmia seen in reproductive-aged women is paroxysmal supraventriculartachycardia.

questions.question: Women with the highest risk of endocarditis in pregnancy are those with
questions.explanation: Women at the highest risk for endocarditis are those with cyanotic cardiac disease and prostheticvalves.The American heart association recommends prophylaxis for dental procedures with:• Prosthetic valves•Unrepaired cyanotic heart defects518• Valvulopathy after heart transplantationAmerican College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists do not recommend endocarditis prophylaxisfor either vaginal or cesarean delivery in the absence of pelvic infection.

questions.question: Which of the following is associated with the highest risk of maternal mortality duringpregnancy?
questions.explanation: Eisenmenger syndrome is the heart disease with the worst prognosis, having a maternal mortalityrate of 50%.The most common cause of death in Eisenmenger's syndrome is right ventricular failure withcardiogenic shock. If antenatal diagnosis of Eisenmenger syndrome is made in the first trimester,termination of pregnancy is advised. Eisenmenger syndrome has the highest risk of maternalmortality. However, since mitral stenosis is the most common cardiac condition in pregnancy, it isthe most common cause of maternal mortality overall.Mitral regurgitation, mitral valve prolapse and pulmonary stenosis are well tolerated duringpregnancy. Severe aortic stenosis can be life-threatening. However, women with mild to moderateaortic valve stenosis may have a relatively low-risk pregnancy.

questions.question: A 32-year-old primigravida delivered a full-term male baby by vaginal delivery. She is aknown case of rheumatic mitral stenosis for 4 years. After the delivery of the placenta, shestarted to bleed profusely. Which among the following should not be used to controlbleeding?
questions.explanation: The given scenario indicates postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) in a primigravida with rheumaticmitral stenosis. Methyl ergometrine is contraindicated in patients with organic heart disease.Contraindications of methyl ergometrine are:•⚫ Twin pregnancy - Second baby gets compromised by tetanic contractions of uterus if given afterdelivery of first baby•Organic cardiac disease - Causes overloading of right heart by squeezing blood from uterinecirculation.• Severe pre-eclampsia and eclampsia•Rh negative mother - Increases chance of fetomaternal transfusion.519
